newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RTRS-TIMELINES - Today in History - Oct 21.
newsitem.headline: RTRS-TIMELINES - Today in History - Oct 21.

text.p: --BIRTHDAYS--
Japanese painter KATSUSHKA HOKUSAI, whose colour prints are still sold worldwide, was born in 1760.
English poet SAMUEL TAYLOR COLERIDGE, who said the true purpose of poetry was to give pleasure "through a medium of beauty", was born in 1772.

The founder of the Nobel Prize, ALFRED NOBEL, was born in 1833. The Swedish industrialist and chemist invented dynamite and founded the award which honours the world's leading scientists, artists and peacemakers.
American trumpet player DIZZIE GILLESPIE, who was responsible for the jazz classic "Night in Tunisia" was born in 1917. He was also one of the originators of bepop.

South African pianist and songwriter MANFRED MANN (MICHAEL LUBOWITZ) was born in 1940. His hits included "Do Wah Diddy Diddy" (1964), "Sha La La" (1964) and "Pretty Flamingo" (1966). From 1972 he was successful in 'Manfred Mann's Earthband" with hits such as "Blinded by the Light" (1976) and "Davy's On the Road Again" (1978).
American screen actress and novelist CARRIE FISHER was born in 1956. Her roles include Prince Leia in "Star Wars" and she wrote "Postcards from the Edge" and "Surrender the Pink".
Lead guitarist with 'Toto' STEVE LUKATHER was born in 1957. He worked with BOZ SCAGGS, OLIVIA NEWTON-JOHN, NEIL DIAMOND and JOE COCKER.
--EVENTS--
1789 : Martial law was imposed in France.
1805 : Britain's famed naval leader Admiral HORATIO

NELSON was killed by a French sniper during a sea battle against Admiral VILLENEUVE. Admiral NELSON was fatally wounded as he stood on the deck of his flagship "Victory". After defeating the combined fleets of Spain and France in the Battle of Trafalgar NELSON emerged victorious only to be killed by a musket ball that entered his left shoulder.
1915 : The first direct transatlantic speech relay by
radio telephone was made by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company from Arlington, Virginia to Paris.
1923 : The world's first planetarium opened in Munich.
1932 : A Norfolk clergyman was defrocked after being

found guilty of "grave scandal". The former Reverend HAROLD DAVIDSON was accused of associating with loose women and making improper suggestions to a waitress. He denied the charges but was found guilty by the Church court. Five years later the ex-minister died after being mauled by a lion at an amusement ground.
1950 : Chinese forces began occupation of Tibet.
1952 : President of the Kenya African movement JOMO
KENYATTA was arrested as Britain crushed the Mau Mau rebels.
1966 : The tiny Welsh town of ABERFAN was hit by a river

of coal when a 162 metre high coal tip slipped. The slip crushed a school, cottages and a farmnhouse killing 144 people, including more than 100 primary school aged children. Safety procedures at the Merthyr Vale Colliery came under scrutiny after the disaster.
1973 : The Sydney Opera House was officially opened by
Her Majesty the Queen. The opening came after almost 20 years of dispute. The building's unusual shape caused costs to rise from an estimated seven million dollars to 100 million dollars.
1979 : The first lady of distance running, GRETE WAITZ,
won the New York marathon for the second consecutive year. The 26-year-old Norwegian school teacher reduced her own record by nearly five minutes.
1986 : The controversial former Attorney-General and High

Court Judge, Mr JUSTICE LIONEL MURPHY, died of cancer. When the judge's illness was diagnosed several months earlier the Government ended investigations by a Parliamentary commission into JUSTICE MURPHY's alleged links with criminals and his suitability to sit on the High Court.
1994 : The U.S. and North Korea signed a landmark deal
under which Pyongyang would freeze and then dismantle its nuclear programme.
